required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Pregnancy-Specific Anxiety on Placental Inflammatory and Oxidative Stress Response and Birth Outcomes
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Pregnancy-Specific Anxiety on Placental Inflammatory and Oxidative Stress Response and Birth Outcomes (MOMS Placenta)

brief_summary.textblock: Explore the associations of prenatal maternal anxiety to placental histologic findings, and the pro-inflammatory, anti-inflammatory, and immunoregulatory cells found in the placenta and determine the effect of maternal anxiety on the association between placental molecular changes on pregnancy and birth and infant outcomes.

detailed_description.textblock:
Purpose: Explore the associations of prenatal maternal anxiety to placental histologic findings, and the pro-inflammatory, anti-inflammatory, and immunoregulatory cells found in the placenta and determine the effect of maternal anxiety on the association between placental molecular changes on pregnancy and birth and infant outcomes.
Subject Population: Prenatal patients receiving obstetrical care at the San Antonio Military Medical Center will be the focused population. Patients must be 18 years or older and planning to deliver at the San Antonio Military Medical Center.
Design: The study is a repeated measures longitudinal design in which patients will complete psychosocial measures of prenatal anxiety, depression, and resilience at multiple data points during their pregnancies (at 12, 16, 24, and 32 weeks gestation). Placental tissue collected after birth will be used to obtain histologic, microscopic, and molecular data. Pregnancy and neonoatal outcome data including gestational age at delivery, infant birthweight, mode of delivery, and pregnancy complications, including pre-eclampsia, gestational hypertension, gestational diabetes, and perinatal and neonatal infections will be collected from the maternal and infant medical records.
Procedures: Participants will complete multiple psychosocial measures at 12, 16, 24, and 32 weeks gestation. Placental tissue will be collected at delivery, gross and microscopic examinations will occur for all placentas of women consented to the study. Histopathological findings will be classified according to standard guidelines and coded into categories that identify vascular malperfusion or uteroplacental vascular insufficiency and maternal inflammatory disorders. Tissue biopsies will be frozen and maintained until they can be batch run. Each biopsy will be homogenized and divided into groups for analysis for RNA expression, protein expression, hormonal and oxidative stress biomarkers. Linear mixed models will be used for all normally distributed continuous data. Binary or dichotomized outcomes will be assessed through mixed model logistic regression. Measurement times, adjusting for age, employment status, prior deliveries, marital status, education, deployment of partner, and MOMS group will be included within the models. Each prenatal variable, anxiety, self-esteem, depression, and resilience will be longitudinally regressed on measurement time to obtain slopes through best linear unbiased predictor. The results slopes will be used to determine any significant effects for prenatal psychosocial scores to pregnancy complications, birth and infant outcomes, and to the physiologic data.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: The study is a repeated measures, longitudinal design
study_design_info.masking_description: Coded histopathology slides will be sent to pathologist for evaluation with only a study number

primary_outcome.measure: Explore the correlations between prenatal maternal anxiety to placental histological findings
primary_outcome.description: Correlate % of participants with high incidences of pregnancy related anxiety measured by the MOMS questionnaire to histological assessment of placenta tissue biopsies measuring Th1, Th2, Oxidative Stress hormones, & RT-PCR for RNA expression.

primary_outcome.measure: Explore the correlations between prenatal maternal anxiety and the function of pro-inflammatory, anti-inflammatory, and immunoregulatory cells found in placental tissue.
primary_outcome.description: Correlate % of participants with high incidences of pregnancy related maternal anxiety measured by the MOMS questionnaire to histological assessment of placenta tissue biopsies measuring oxidative stress hormone biomarkers.

primary_outcome.measure: Determine the effect of maternal anxiety on between placental molecular changes on pregnancy and birth and infant outcomes.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion and average of 1 year
primary_outcome.description: Correlate% of participants with high maternal anxiety on birth outcomes which will be assessed using MOMS post-partum psychosocial questionnaire, collecting birth and infant delivery outcomes such as birth wt, delivery complications, antenatal history, & infant complications. Placenta tissue will be analyzed through punch tissue biopsies for immunological, inflammatory and hormonal changes examining gross placental features, vascular malperfusion or insufficiency, and maternal inflammatory disorders.

arm_group.description: Women that are currently in the Mentors Offering Maternal Support (M-O-M-S) research program as well as pregnant women entering prenatal care in the first trimester, who are not in the M-O-M-S program may participate in the study. Arms Assigned Interventions Experimental: M-O-M-S Intervention M-O-M-S intervention is 10, 1 hour prenatal mentored support groups No Intervention: Routine Prenatal Care Routine prenatal care in accordance with the Department of Defense Pregnancy Guidelines

intervention.description: Behavioral: Mentors Offering Maternal Support (M-O-M-S) 10, 1 hour, structured classes meeting every-other-week in person beginning in the first trimester of pregnancy and unlimited access to mentor support.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- All Active Duty and DoD beneficiary gravid women,
- 18 years of age or older,
- Receiving prenatal care at SAMMC,
- English speaking
Exclusion Criteria:
- Military dependent daughters
- VA beneficiaries

responsible_party.investigator_title: Professor, Brigadier General Lillian Dunlap Endowed Chair
